topics.title: Feather-brick-dump truck burnout warning model
topics.summary: Jonny introduces his metaphor for how burnout escalates from subtle signals (feather) to serious consequences (dump truck), emphasizing the importance of noticing early bodily feedback and adjusting before crisis hits.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Jonny Miller and the episode’s focus: nervous system mastery for calm, resilience, and confidence. He previews breathing tools, burnout detection, emotional debt, and the APE practice.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Teal (job search platform) and Vanta (security compliance automation).

topics.title: Jonny’s origin story and catalyst event
topics.summary: Jonny shares his tech/startup background, his burnout, and the pivotal tragedy of his fiancée’s death that led him into deep study of breathwork, meditation, and nervous system regulation.

topics.title: Bottom-up regulation: state over story
topics.summary: Jonny explains why physiology-first approaches (especially breath) often outperform cognitive reframing: there’s more body-to-brain signaling than brain-to-body, so changing bodily state can quickly shift thoughts and feelings.

topics.title: Calming breath drill: 4-4-8 plus humming
topics.summary: They practice a downshifting routine (inhale 4, hold 4, exhale 8) and add humming to deepen calm. Jonny explains mechanisms like nitric oxide release and vagus nerve stimulation.

topics.title: Building a personal toolkit: if-this-then-breathe
topics.summary: Jonny recommends matching practices to contexts (meetings, Zoom calls, social anxiety, end-of-day downshifts) and creating simple triggers like “if overwhelmed, then hum” to make regulation automatic.

topics.title: Physiological sigh and quick downshifting
topics.summary: They discuss Huberman’s “physiological sigh” as a fast calming tool and how sighing naturally signals nervous system downregulation after breath practices or when feeling safe.

topics.title: Energizing breath drill: espresso/bellows breath
topics.summary: Jonny teaches an activating practice (rapid nasal exhales driven from the belly) as a gentler alternative to more intense methods. They discuss when to use it and how to combine activation with later grounding.

topics.title: Practice design: daily reps to remember under stress
topics.summary: Jonny advises a short daily morning practice to build familiarity so you can recall tools when stressed. They clarify timing, durations, and adapting inhale/exhale ratios to capacity.

topics.title: Interoception: training the body-awareness sense
topics.summary: Jonny introduces interoception as a trainable ‘sixth sense’ for tracking internal sensations and early anxiety signals. He notes correlations with ADHD/PTSD and decision-making advantages from stronger interoceptive skill.

topics.title: APE framework: awareness, posture, emotion
topics.summary: Jonny shares APE as a quick self-check to shift state: widen awareness, adjust posture, and name/feel emotions and sensations. They discuss adding breath and using it in meetings or before calls.

topics.title: Burnout detection via body signals and commitments
topics.summary: Jonny connects interoception to burnout prevention, giving a personal example of noticing exhaustion/tension after overcommitting and then restructuring his schedule to reduce load.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Miro (collaboration and project organization platform).

topics.title: Emotional debt: allostatic load and early signs
topics.summary: Jonny defines emotional debt as uncompleted stress cycles stored as allostatic load, leading to fragility and burnout. Signs include disproportionate reactivity, poor sleep, relationship strain, and reliance on substances to downshift.

topics.title: Paying off emotional debt with somatic approaches
topics.summary: Jonny argues talk therapy alone can miss the body’s stored stress; he recommends building safety, self-regulation, and ‘emotional fluidity’ to feel and complete stuck responses. He cites breathwork and modalities like Somatic Experiencing and Hakomi.

topics.title: Recognizing dysregulation patterns: fight vs freeze
topics.summary: Jonny describes how emotional debt shows up as dysregulation: hypervigilance, dissociation into the head, and disproportionate reactions. He distinguishes common patterns (shutdown/freeze vs fight/attack) and emphasizes downshifting before deciding or responding.
